componenttext: So just coming back to the M&A comment. Certainly, I understand the opportunities there, but we haven't seen any transactions in some time. So can you just talk a little bit about the landscape? And presumably, you've had plenty of sort of operational flexibility to do another deal here in the last few quarters. So has it been price? Has it been opportunities? What are the kind of the things that you're looking forward to be able to make another step forward here?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we said at the end of last year -- at the end of 2014 that our primary objective for 2015 was a successful integration of tw telecom, and so that has been our primary focus. We believe that, that is the most important use of our time a
componenttext: Well, first of all, we said at the end of last year -- at the end of 2014 that our primary objective for 2015 was a successful integration of tw telecom, and so that has been our primary focus. We believe that, that is the most important use of our time and resources, and so that is where we focused throughout 2015. There are lots of opportunities out there for M&A from a variety of different perspectives, some are to expand our footprint, some are to expand our capabilities in new products and services, some are to expand our customer base. And we'll continue to look at those from a disciplined perspective. But up until now, our focus has been integrating tw telecom, and we think we're in a position now to continue looking forward.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And given -- Sunit, given your new leverage target, would you be willing to go above that target temporarily to do the right deal?
componenttext: And given -- Sunit, given your new leverage target, would you be willing to go above that target temporarily to do the right deal?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think we've been very disciplined on the target. We've never really kind of gone above the target. So I think like as we've done in the past, we would look to be within that range pro forma for synergies for anything we would look at. So we're not r
componenttext: No, I think we've been very disciplined on the target. We've never really kind of gone above the target. So I think like as we've done in the past, we would look to be within that range pro forma for synergies for anything we would look at. So we're not really -- and we are already within the target. We have 3.8x and with the EBITDA growth we see every quarter, we'll see that number come down approaching 3 over the next year. So I think, yes, I mean, we'd stay within the range on any acquisition pro forma for synergies.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, a follow-up regarding synergies. So I recognize that it gets harder to break these things out as time goes on. And you're not going to disclose any specific stats going forward, but broadly speaking, what's been embedded in your 2016 outlook from a
componenttext: First, a follow-up regarding synergies. So I recognize that it gets harder to break these things out as time goes on. And you're not going to disclose any specific stats going forward, but broadly speaking, what's been embedded in your 2016 outlook from a synergy perspective?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think that -- it's been 1 year and 3 months after. So the teams run based on what their targets are for the year from a budget perspective. There's no kind of distinction between synergies and nonsynergies. So it's embedded within the targets we
componenttext: Yes. So I think that -- it's been 1 year and 3 months after. So the teams run based on what their targets are for the year from a budget perspective. There's no kind of distinction between synergies and nonsynergies. So it's embedded within the targets we set for various areas. So I think that -- again, I don't think -- I mean, in general, I think, from an operating expense perspective, we have done a lot. There won't be as much from an operating expense perspective other than as we consolidate systems and platforms, we'll continue to get some savings on the margin. But as Jeff pointed out, we're also looking to expand our sales force and associated support with that. On the network expense side, I think it's mostly continued optimization that will benefit us. Over time we might see some benefit in operating expenses on the real estate side. But again, it's within the guidance we provided.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then maybe one sort of macro question. Some folks are worried that we might be headed towards a weaker economic environment in the U.S. And I'd be interested in hearing your thoughts regarding how sensitive you think your business is to s
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then maybe one sort of macro question. Some folks are worried that we might be headed towards a weaker economic environment in the U.S. And I'd be interested in hearing your thoughts regarding how sensitive you think your business is to swings in the macro economy. And obviously, during the last recession, I think the business struggled a bit, but your mix has changed a lot since then. You might also argue that you're important to the services, you provide to your customers has improved recently.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're exactly right, Nick. And if you look at our mix, we're 73% enterprise, 23% wholesale. The last downturn -- major downturn in the economy where we had a very different mix at that point. And I also think you're right in the statement that th
componenttext: I think you're exactly right, Nick. And if you look at our mix, we're 73% enterprise, 23% wholesale. The last downturn -- major downturn in the economy where we had a very different mix at that point. And I also think you're right in the statement that the services we provide are absolutely critical to our customers. And as customers, if they're going through difficulty, It's not a change in their bandwidth demand, it's not a change in the complexity of the network environment, the increased demand for security services, all of those things will drive customers to looking at new solutions and technology transitions as opposed to causing them to shy away from making those decisions. So we think we're in a very good position and that the ability of Level 3 to perform is up to our execution.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one final thing I would add to that is, we have been gaining market share vis-à-vis our competitors. And I think that opportunity continues to exist for us.
componenttext: And one final thing I would add to that is, we have been gaining market share vis-à-vis our competitors. And I think that opportunity continues to exist for us.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Barry McCarver with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Barry McCarver with Stephens.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 2 questions. I guess, first off, you highlighted the strength in dark fiber. I know that's been a highlight for several quarters. Within the product lines, do you expect that continue to be strong driver for the business? And what other lines might als
componenttext: So 2 questions. I guess, first off, you highlighted the strength in dark fiber. I know that's been a highlight for several quarters. Within the product lines, do you expect that continue to be strong driver for the business? And what other lines might also you point out as being a highlight? And then just secondly, in regards to M&A, I certainly feel like there's a certain competitive advantage of continuing to move into new markets and look for new footprints. Do you view M&A strategically that way? Or do you feel comfortable with your existing footprint being able to provide plenty of growth for the foreseeable future?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me -- I'll let Sunit comment directly on dark fiber, but let me talk about one of the strengths of Level 3, and that's our ability to match our services to a customer's networking needs. And so we have customers and applications for those custom
componenttext: Sure. Let me -- I'll let Sunit comment directly on dark fiber, but let me talk about one of the strengths of Level 3, and that's our ability to match our services to a customer's networking needs. And so we have customers and applications for those customers where dark fiber is absolutely an appropriate solution. If you want to tie 2 locally located data centers together, dark fiber is a good solution for that. If you want to tie 2 data centers across the country together, our 100 gig laid products are good solutions for that. If you want to tie a data center to a branch office, our IP VPN products are good for that. And so we look at that overall comprehensive portfolio and recognize that our customers have very -- a variety of different networking challenges that they are trying to solve. And so we match our technologies. We don't -- we're not limited to just CDN, we're not limited to just Internet. We match our technologies and our solutions to their working needs, and so we think that's a strong capability that we offer versus most of our competitors. With respect to M&A, we are very pleased with our footprint, but we want to continue to expand our footprint, both in depth and in geography. So if you look at EMEA for example, I mentioned that we are focused on expanding in 4 key markets. That means going richer and deeper in fiber in the U.K. but also richer and deeper in fiber in Germany, France and Benelux. And so we'll continue to look at those both organically and inorganically of how we put our cash to work to drive the growth for Level 3. Sunit?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think on your questions within product area, so dark fiber has been a good growth for us, but remember we have pretty diversified portfolio and a comprehensive portfolio of products and services and more solution-driven as Jeff mentioned, based
componenttext: Yes, so I think on your questions within product area, so dark fiber has been a good growth for us, but remember we have pretty diversified portfolio and a comprehensive portfolio of products and services and more solution-driven as Jeff mentioned, based on what our customers' needs are. We continue to see dark fiber performing well over the next couple of years as some of our customers' scale needs are large and that solution works for them. Then there are other areas. CDN, we've talked about, we told -- we said last year, we made a significant investment there. We're beginning to see the benefits there. There are other areas that we've made investments, so we'll talk about in the future, like security services that Jeff has talked about. We continue to make reasonable sized investments in that area. That's something we'll be able to talk about more tangibly later in the year or next year. So these are some of the areas. But in general, the basic message, I think, is the demand drivers for bandwidth continuing strength for all of the things that Jeff cited, and that's what we are leveraged towards.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow up on the leverage questions you've been getting. The decision to lower the top end of the range, I'm just wondering what drove that. For example, did you get any maybe color or commentary out of the credit markets that your incrementa
componenttext: Just a quick follow up on the leverage questions you've been getting. The decision to lower the top end of the range, I'm just wondering what drove that. For example, did you get any maybe color or commentary out of the credit markets that your incremental funding costs could be a lot lower if you're willing to commit to a lower floor? And then you guys provided a really constructive view on what supports your revenue outlook for this year. And Jeff, I was hoping you can maybe just provide a little more color in terms of what's behind that? Specifically, how much of that outlook is based on the demand environment in general, what you're seeing in sales funnels, what you're seeing in client spend? And to what extent does it represent an improved ability to tackle those opportunities because of where you are in the integration of TWTC and some of the other initiatives you've been pursuing to make the company more efficient?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the leverage question, and Jeff can take the other one. But I think on the leverage, keep in mind, we've been now saying a couple of years that we want to be at the low end of 3 to 5x. So that says that we were kind of already saying 3x for the
componenttext: I'll take the leverage question, and Jeff can take the other one. But I think on the leverage, keep in mind, we've been now saying a couple of years that we want to be at the low end of 3 to 5x. So that says that we were kind of already saying 3x for the last 2 [ph] years. So taking the top end of that from 5 to 4x wasn't as big a deal other than just to establish a firm marker, and we think a 3 to 4x range is good and being at the low end of that is good. So even though we've taken the top down from 5 to 4x, we have been saying for the last 2 [ph] years, we wanted to be at the low end of 3 to 5x. It wasn't driven in any part by anything to do with the credit markets. I think we've always been pretty firm and steady in our guidance there.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think that we're at an intersection in the market for Level 3. We have an exceptional network that is -- it's global in nature, it's diverse in its geography, it has capabilities across that spectrum of products sets. We're able to layer on sec
componenttext: Yes, and I think that we're at an intersection in the market for Level 3. We have an exceptional network that is -- it's global in nature, it's diverse in its geography, it has capabilities across that spectrum of products sets. We're able to layer on security services, CDN services, managed services, professional services on top of that to help our customers do the migrations in technology and the transitions in technologies that they have to do. We've made great progress in the integration of tw telecom, and we have an excellent workforce across the globe, focused on making Level 3 the best provider. And then we have a market that's moving toward our capabilities, not away from our capabilities. Customers need the types of services that Level 3 is offering. The need for that is continuing to grow. They are operating in very complicated environments with many external threats with technology changes that they have to implement within their businesses, with new business opportunities and other things coming from things like Internet of Things and opportunities to increase the flexibility of their network with technologies like SDN and NSV. And so we think we're at a great intersection between where the network is, where the customers are going and our capabilities to deliver that based on the work that we've done over the last year.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Hodulik with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Hodulik with UBS.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chris for John. Going back to the install revenues that occurred in North American enterprise in 2015, can you highlight what quarters those benefits were mainly realized in? And how we should think about the quarterly comps over the course of 201
componenttext: This is Chris for John. Going back to the install revenues that occurred in North American enterprise in 2015, can you highlight what quarters those benefits were mainly realized in? And how we should think about the quarterly comps over the course of 2016?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, I think, obviously, we saw strength in the third quarter that we talked about and there were some in the first quarter, but, I would say, the first 3 quarters more than the fourth quarter.
componenttext: Sure. I mean, I think, obviously, we saw strength in the third quarter that we talked about and there were some in the first quarter, but, I would say, the first 3 quarters more than the fourth quarter.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in regard to the CapEx, I believe, you have some integration CapEx that's actually going to fall off year-over-year, which would give you some added room for growth in investments. Can you talk about what the components of your budget for next y
componenttext: Okay. And in regard to the CapEx, I believe, you have some integration CapEx that's actually going to fall off year-over-year, which would give you some added room for growth in investments. Can you talk about what the components of your budget for next year? And what product areas or regions you're most focused on at this point?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think the message is one, we are spending more CapEx in dollars in 2016 compared to 2015 since our revenue -- total revenue is growing. And you're right in that the since we have less -- much less in integration CapEx in 2016 compared to '15, w
componenttext: Sure. So I think the message is one, we are spending more CapEx in dollars in 2016 compared to 2015 since our revenue -- total revenue is growing. And you're right in that the since we have less -- much less in integration CapEx in 2016 compared to '15, we do have more CapEx just from that perspective that we're putting to work. In terms of the components, as we've said in the past, most of our capital expenditure is success based driven by customer contracts. About $300 million to $350 million is what we have described as sort of maintenance upgrade-type CapEx. The rest is expansion CapEx. The thrust of the expansion capital this year will be some of the things that Jeff mentioned, which is expanding our network footprint, both deeper within existing geographies and in new geographies. I think that'll be a big chunk. We are spending capital for data centers on a select basis in different -- in some regions. We are spending capital for upgrading or putting in more capacity on our subsea systems. We are investing capital on long-haul dark fiber outs where needed. So these are several different areas that we're investing capital. The other area we're going to be investing more capital is an area we cited earlier, the security business we talked about. We're going to continue to put more capital in that area. But, Jeff, I don't know if you're going to add to any of those areas [indiscernible] key things.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible].
componenttext: [indiscernible].

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious with the fiber that you have and the series of acquisitions that you've done, the number of buildings that you connect to, is there a way to frame any advantage you may have in terms of the cost to expand the network to meet customer needs? O
componenttext: Just curious with the fiber that you have and the series of acquisitions that you've done, the number of buildings that you connect to, is there a way to frame any advantage you may have in terms of the cost to expand the network to meet customer needs? Or would that -- might relate into a pricing advantage because of the cost structure that you may be able to achieve?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. That's a great question. I think this is the -- we'd -- we call the network advantage because the more network you have, the more closer you are to buildings. So the advantage in winning new business is 2 for 1, because you're connected to more buil
componenttext: Sure. That's a great question. I think this is the -- we'd -- we call the network advantage because the more network you have, the more closer you are to buildings. So the advantage in winning new business is 2 for 1, because you're connected to more buildings, you have a higher margin or lower cost structure or more degrees of freedom to win the business. But in addition to your point, to tie in new buildings in any particular customer proposal we are going for, our cost to get to that is generally lower than other providers just because of the depth and capillarity of our network. So -- and the other key point there is because we operate in the number of geographies we do, more often than not, when a customer has a need, we can get to the more of their locations on that than our competitors do, which is why, one of the reasons we talked about acquisitions is that not only do they give you synergies and accretive free cash flow per share, but actually improve your competitive and strategic positon and the durability or the advantage that you have vis-à-vis your competition.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Phil Cusick with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Phil Cusick with JPMorgan.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Eric in for Phil. Just maybe to follow up on M&A. With its current macro headwinds outside the U.S., do you still view international expansion as more or less attractive at this time? And if so -- if it is still more attractive, are you more inter
componenttext: This is Eric in for Phil. Just maybe to follow up on M&A. With its current macro headwinds outside the U.S., do you still view international expansion as more or less attractive at this time? And if so -- if it is still more attractive, are you more interested in lit or dark assets? And how do you feel about the current valuation of these assets?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Several questions in there. I will try and get them all, Eric. If I don't, ask again. If you look at our capabilities, we have very rich long-haul and metro assets throughout the U.S. We don't have as rich in EMEA and LATAM. And so obviously, those are ar
componenttext: Several questions in there. I will try and get them all, Eric. If I don't, ask again. If you look at our capabilities, we have very rich long-haul and metro assets throughout the U.S. We don't have as rich in EMEA and LATAM. And so obviously, those are areas that we want to continue to expand. Whether that's through organic or inorganic, we want to make sure that we build an infrastructure that matches our opportunity in those markets. And so we believe that we have great opportunity to do that. With respect to pricing of those types of assets, I don't really have any comment on that. We will be disciplined. If we look at M&A activities -- and make sure that we believe that the value that we're getting is appropriate for what we're paying and we'll continue to use that discipline that we've demonstrated in the past and making sure that we believe we can execute on the integration in the way that we've done in the past and we'll continue to focus on those things.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And you mentioned that you're expecting stronger growth in LATAM this year. What are you seeing in terms of the macro headwinds there? And how do you expect that to impact you guys?
componenttext: Got it. And you mentioned that you're expecting stronger growth in LATAM this year. What are you seeing in terms of the macro headwinds there? And how do you expect that to impact you guys?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in LATAM, I think, we did get impacted by the macro headwinds last year. We talked about it, we adjusted our expectations middle of the year for LATAM. I think that our LATAM business finished quite strongly in the fourth quarter. And I think what
componenttext: Yes. So in LATAM, I think, we did get impacted by the macro headwinds last year. We talked about it, we adjusted our expectations middle of the year for LATAM. I think that our LATAM business finished quite strongly in the fourth quarter. And I think what's driving it is, what Jeff and I have been talking about, which is just a good demand backdrop for bandwidth as the bandwidth maturity level adoption level in North America is lower in North America and they're just raising up that curve. So we are benefiting from all kinds of drivers, whether it's from the enterprise side directly or content, it is a big driver of our growth there. So it's just a demand backdrop for bandwidth is what's driving it. So we do expect better performance in LATAM on a constant currency basis.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line up Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line up Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, it seems like the Internet companies and their cloud strategies, the top 5 or 6 guys are really changing the dynamics of the industry quite a bit. They're spending a huge amount on CapEx. Could you maybe just talk about how you're partnering with th
componenttext: Jeff, it seems like the Internet companies and their cloud strategies, the top 5 or 6 guys are really changing the dynamics of the industry quite a bit. They're spending a huge amount on CapEx. Could you maybe just talk about how you're partnering with them? Or how it's kind of -- are you or -- maybe what -- the customer relationships are changing and the network relationships are changing as you either compete with them or partner with them?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, absolutely, and we do partner with them. All those companies that you could cite are customers of Level 3 or partners of Level 3. So we focus very much on partnering with them. We also recognize that they are pools of demand that our customers want
componenttext:
Sure, absolutely, and we do partner with them. All those companies that you could cite are customers of Level 3 or partners of Level 3. So we focus very much on partnering with them. We also recognize that they are pools of demand that our customers want to get too. And so we are connecting to them and building to them very consistently and are the -- I'd argue are the best connected globally to many of those types of companies. And so we'll continue to partner, we'll continue to build to them. The other thing that we're trying to do is change and we are doing is changing the way networks operate, so that the enterprise customers can take advantage of those resources more effectively. Historically, networks have been very inflexible. You build up capacity, you nail that capacity up and it just stays there and that's all you have. We have changed with our Adaptive Network Control capabilities and our Cloud Connect Solutions products. We have changed that dynamic and are creating flexible networks that allow enterprise customers to more effectively utilize those cloud environments and access those different pools of demand with very flexible network design. So we'll continue to partner with them and continue to focus on making sure that Level 3 is the most connected and the best equipped to take advantage of that for our customers.
Thank you. With that, I'd like to close the call with just a few thoughts. As evidenced by our continued growth in market share, our strategy to position Level 3 as the premier provider of global communication services is working. We believe we're at the intersection of the best network, the best people and the right market opportunity to continue to grow. The ability to generate significant free cash flow is evident in our performance last year and our expectation for 2016 and remains a focus for the business through continued profitable growth. We remain focused on our enterprise networking customers and on providing a differentiated customer experience. 
Lastly, I'd like to thank our dedicated employees around the globe for their significant contributions in 2015. They are the engine that drives Level 3. As always, thank you for joining today's call. Thank you for your questions and for your support of Level 3. 
Operator, that concludes the call.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff. We would like to thank everyone for your participation and for using the Level 3 conferencing service today. This does conclude the conference call. We ask that you please disconnect your lines. Have a great day, everyone.
componenttext: Thank you, Jeff. We would like to thank everyone for your participation and for using the Level 3 conferencing service today. This does conclude the conference call. We ask that you please disconnect your lines. Have a great day, everyone.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Level 3 First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Thursday, April 28, 2016.I would now like to turn the conference over to
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Level 3 First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Thursday, April 28, 2016.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Valerie Finberg, Vice President, Corporate Communications and Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dmitra. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice Pres
componenttext:
Thank you, Dmitra. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for the Level 3 Communications First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With us on the call today are Jeff Storey, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Sunit Patel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Prior period results discussed today are presented on a pro forma basis adjusted to exclude the company's Venezuelan subsidiary's operations, which were deconsolidated at the end of the third quarter 2015 and adjusted to reflect changes made to customer assignments between the wholesale and enterprise channels at the beginning of 2016 due to mergers between certain customers and other changes. 
Unless otherwise noted, revenue and sales comparisons to prior periods are provided on a year-over-year and constant currency basis. 
I'd like to call your attention to the safe harbor statement that begins on Page 2 of our 1Q '16 earnings presentation. The presentation and remarks contain forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Results may vary significantly from those statements, and additional information is available in the Investor Relations section of the Level 3 website and in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
We will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP measures are available in the earnings presentation.
The earnings presentation and all of our other earnings materials are available in the Investor Relations section of the Level 3 website at investors.level3.com. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Before we get into our results this morning, I'd like to start out on a personal note. As most of you know, I'm recently back from medical leave following heart surgery. The surgery
componenttext:
Thanks, Valerie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. 
Before we get into our results this morning, I'd like to start out on a personal note. As most of you know, I'm recently back from medical leave following heart surgery. The surgery and my recovery have gone extremely well, and I'm very excited to be back at work, but I wanted to expect my thanks to the kind wishes I received from so many people on this call. Your cards, notes and words of support were very meaningful to me, and I greatly appreciate it. 
I'd also like to mention the outpouring of support I received from Level 3 employees. I mentioned a number of times before the outstanding employees we have, but as I was thinking about this call, I wanted to take the opportunity to really illustrate the point. 
One of the things that touched me most during my absence was literally thousands of notes and e-mails I received from employees. Of course, they wished me well, hoping for a speedy recovery and a complete recovery, but there were also many notes that expressed another thought. Many employees said things like, "Jeff, while you're out, don't worry about Level 3. We've got this." Or they said, "Jeff, you focus on recovery, we'll focus on driving the business." 
I think those notes really demonstrate something that I've known for a long time. The strength of Level 3 is our employees. We care about each other. We support each other. We take ownership of our own responsibilities that happily take on more to support a coworker in need. Ultimately, each of our employees are individually and personally committed to the success of the company. I really like to thank them for their support and all they do to drive Level 3 forward. 
I'd also like to thank Sunit for serving as interim CEO while I was out as well as the entire leadership team for keeping the business on track and executing against our strategy. It's gratifying to see the strength and depth of the leadership team we have built at the company. 
In fact, the focus by the entire team on profitable growth is evident in our first quarter results with expanding margins, strong growth and adjusted EBITDA and continued generation of free cash flow. On today's call, we'll have a slight departure from our usual approach. I'll provide a few initial thoughts on our view of the market and the Level 3 strategy. Sunit will provide a first quarter operational update and our detailed financial results. After that, we'll open it up for your questions. 
With that, I'll now turn to what we're seeing in the market and our strategy, which is designed to both maximize our opportunity for the long term and enable us to take advantage of the current environment. The increasingly digital and increasingly connected world is creating the need for businesses to be fully networked across their operations. At the same time, the compelling economics of the cloud are driving enterprises to include migration to the cloud as a key element of their IT strategy. 
Combined with the proliferation of connected devices and an ever more threatening security landscape for, a hybrid cloud strategy is leading to hybrid networking for many enterprises. These market factors benefit Level 3. Our robust product portfolio and capabilities that range from dark fiber and advanced transport services like 100 gig waves all the way up to CDN and our innovative threat intelligence services position Level 3 well to meet enterprises' complex hybrid networking needs. 
As we look to 2016 and beyond, our strategy is unchanged. We remain focused on operational excellence throughout the business, providing a superior experience to our customers and developing the products and capabilities to meet their evolving needs. 
There are 4 key elements to our strategy. First, focusing on enterprises as the company's growth engine. We've been successful in capturing share of the global enterprise communications market, but our share remains low, and we see a continuing opportunity to grow across all 3 regions. In particular, companies who view the network as fundamental to their business strategy and an enabler of growth in their own businesses are targets for our continued growth. 
Second, continue investing in a comprehensive and evolving product portfolio. As I mentioned, the transformation in the communications industry is underway, and we continue to develop the capabilities we need to solve our customers' needs for growth, efficiency and security. 
Third, expanding our network and building directly to our customers' locations. We believe that having our customers on our network or on-net enables us to provide better network performance and reliability as well as an improved experience for our customers. 
And fourth but certainly not least, providing an excellent customer experience. We are investing in operational excellence to continually improve our customers' interactions with Level 3 across every aspect of the business. 
Central to our strategy is our vision of one that I've discussed before, one set of products that we take to an expanding market, one network to deliver those products globally, one set of operational support systems to enable a differentiated customer experience and one team with the singular goal of making Level 3 the premier provider of enterprise networking services. 
Level 3 is a growth business. As I said on our fourth quarter earnings call, our goal is to achieve 8% year-over-year CNS enterprise revenue growth. While we aren't there yet, as a team, we are working toward accelerating growth. Our strategy and the operating plans that support our strategy are designed to deliver a differentiated customer experience and drive growth. Investing in the key areas of products, network, systems and customer service excellence are priorities for the business. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Sunit to discuss the first quarter results. Sunit?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Jeff, before I start, on behalf of everyone here at Level 3, we are happy you are back. Turning to Slide 3. I'll start by covering key areas of focus on operational progress for the first quarter before I get
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Jeff, before I start, on behalf of everyone here at Level 3, we are happy you are back. 
Turning to Slide 3. I'll start by covering key areas of focus on operational progress for the first quarter before I get to the financial results. As a company, we continue strive towards operational excellence, and we are executing on many initiatives to drive growth. We are adding to our sales organization and improving sales productivity. We continue to expand the Level 3 network and enhance our products. We are operating well from a bottom line and cash flow perspective and remain focused on driving better top line growth. 
In the first quarter, from a sales perspective, production held steady year-over-year and grew nicely sequentially. Sales productivity continue to increase. We continue to improve our sales model, implementing a unified strategy to ensure consistency across our markets. Our local sales presence and willingness to bring fiber to customer locations have been a differentiator in our success. 
From a headcount perspective, the first quarter is typically when we see a higher level of churn from our quota-bearing headcount. During the first quarter of this year, we held quota-bearing headcount relatively steady, declining by roughly 10 people in the quarter. At the same time, we added more than 20 specialized nonquota-bearing security and CDN sales representatives to help identify and close opportunities for this growth products. The size of our overall sales organization has increased, and we expect that quota-bearing headcount will grow for the full year. 
During the quarter, we further consolidated our legacy billing systems and are now on a single platform across North America and EMEA. With the consolidation of Latin America into our end state environment later this year, we expect to be on a single global billing platform by the end of the third quarter. 
Additionally, we now have a single customer self-service portal interface across North America and EMEA, with plans to incorporate Latin America in the future. 
From a product perspective, we continue investing to meet the needs of our customers. For example, we continue to strengthen our cloud offering with the introduction of Microsoft Office 365 to our Cloud Connect Solutions ecosystem. In general, we are seeing more secure enterprise connections to the cloud, driving revenue growth. 
Additionally, we were recently named an advanced partner in the AWS partner network, providing network connections to improve enterprise and public sector access to the AWS Cloud computing platform and services. I'd like to note at that Level 3 is connected to more AWS Direct Connect locations globally than any other network service provider. 
Wave length revenue continues to grow, and we are seeing increased adoption of 100 gig wave services. Driven by strong interest from customers, we continue to invest in our security solutions. In February, Level 3 opened its first distributor denial of service or DDoS scrubbing center in LatAm. This addition complements the 8 other scrubbing locations we have across North America, where we have 5; and EMEA, where we have 3. 
During the quarter, in addition to the investments we made to the sales force and our product portfolio, we also continue to expand our on-net billing footprint across all 3 of our regions. 
Turning to our results from a financial perspective. I'd like to start with some highlights for the quarter, which can be found on Slide 4 of our presentation. We grew Core Network Services, or CNS, revenue by 4%. We grew CNS enterprise revenue 6%, grew North America CNS enterprise revenues 6% year-over-year and approximately 2% sequentially. We increased EBITDA by 15% to $710 million and generated strong free cash flow of $213 million. 
Turning to revenue results on Slide 5. As we've seen over the last year, the difference in constant currency and as-reported growth rates can be attributed to the strength of the dollar against many other currencies. As you can see on this slide, we have provided revenue growth rates by region on both a constant currency and an as-reported basis. Overall, total revenue grew 2.3%, and CNS revenue grew 3.6%. Within CNS, enterprise grew 5.7% while wholesale declined 1.4%. 
On a regional basis, we had a solid quarter in North America, highlighted by sequential CNS enterprise revenue growth of about 2%. In the first quarter, EMEA CNS revenue declined 4.9%, and CNS enterprise revenue, excluding U.K. government, declined 0.5%. 
First quarter enterprise sales, excluding U.K. government, were up 20% year-over-year and 16% sequentially. During the quarter, certain large disconnects and the timing of professional services and onetime items pressured revenue growth. 
We have invested in sales and marketing resources in the region, including new sales leaders in France and Germany. Additionally, we've been investing in product capabilities in the region, including CDN, security and Voice Complete, which should help drive revenue growth for the remainder of the year. 
In Latin America, CNS enterprise revenue remained strong, growing 10%. Also, CNS revenue growth was flat due to a few nondisconnects. 
Wholesale Voice Services revenue, or WVS, declined 18% to $104 million in the first quarter of 2016. For the full year, we continue to expect WVS revenue to decline by approximately 10%. As we said last quarter, excluding U.K. government revenue, we generally expect total CNS and CNS enterprise revenue growth to be stronger in 2016 compared to 2015. 
Looking at first quarter results, although EMEA started a bit weaker than expected, we are maintaining our full year 2016 outlook. 
Our revenue mix can be found on Slide 6, with North America representing 82% of our CNS revenue followed by EMEA at 10% and Latin America at 8%. Our enterprise customers represent 72% of CNS revenue while wholesale customers make up the remaining 28%. 
Turning to Slide 7 and revenue results by product group. IP and data services grew 7.2%. Transport and fiber declined 0.3%. Voice services grew 2.4%, and the colocation and data services revenue declined 0.5%. 
a Few highlights from an individual product perspective include CDN growth of 4%, dark fiber growth of 11% and managed security growth of 46%. From a pricing standpoint, we haven't seen much change over the last several quarters. 
Moving to Slide 8. Network Access margin expanded to 66.2% compared to 64.5% in the first quarter 2015. The improvement in Network Access margin was driven by continued high-margin CNS revenue growth combined with low-margin WVS revenue decline and continued expense savings from network consolidation. 
Turning to Slide 9. Adjusted EBITDA was $710 million for the first quarter of 2016. This compares to $620 million in the first quarter 2015. The improvement in adjusted EBITDA was primarily driven by the operating leverage from CNS revenue growth, the full benefit of synergies realized in 2015 and continued initiatives to manage costs. We also continue to expand adjusted EBITDA margin, which improved to 34.6% in the first quarter of 2016 compared to 30.5% in the first quarter 2015. 
The company generated free cash flow of $213 million in the quarter compared to $42 million from the year-ago quarter. After the close of the quarter, the company redeemed $775 million of our 7% senior notes funded by the net proceeds from our 700 -- our new $775 million, 5.25% senior notes which closed during the first quarter. As a result of this transaction, in the second quarter 2016, we expect to recognize a loss before taxes of $40 million or $0.11 in basic earnings per share on the extinguishment and modification of debt. 
We exited the quarter with our net debt-to-adjusted EBITDA ratio of 3.7x and are focused on getting to the low end of our target leverage range of 3 to 4x. In the first quarter of 2016, the company generated net income of $124 million and basic and diluted earnings per share of $0.35 and $0.34, respectively. 
While the effective income tax rate in the first quarter was 43%, we continue to expect our GAAP income tax rate to average about 30% for the full year 2016. The effective tax rate can fluctuate significantly in any quarter for discrete or unusual events. We expect the rate in the second quarter to be in the 15% to 20% range. 
Turning to the business outlook on Slide 10. We remain confident in our performance for the remainder of the year. With our continued focus on profitable revenue growth and strong adjusted EBITDA results in the first quarter 2016, we are increasing our outlook for full year 2016 adjusted EBITDA growth. We now expect full year 2016 adjusted EBITDA growth of 10% to 12% compared to our previous outlook of 9% to 12%. 
In addition, we continue to expected generate free cash flow of $1 billion to $1.1 billion. Additionally, we've lowered our full year interest expense estimates based on our recent capital markets transactions. 
We also updated our noncash compensation estimate for 2016 to $170 million from $130 million as we had underestimated the expenses for employees who will become retirement eligible in 2016 and certain stock trends. 
In summary, we are focused on sales momentum by growing both the sales force and sales productivity. We are driving profitable growth by executing on the investments we made through our network expansion and product portfolio enhancement initiatives. Finally, across the business, we are maintaining financial discipline and driving improved efforts to improve operational excellence and customer experience. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Valerie to start the Q&A.

componenttext: Thank you, Simon. Yes, the sales bookings were for EMEA, and as I pointed out, the enterprise sales bookings were up 20% from a year ago. And also as we said and I'll confirm, yes, we think that you will start seeing EMEA's results improve for the remainder of the year, which will include from the second quarter going forward.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is not a macro issue?
componenttext: So this is not a macro issue?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's not a macro issue. We had some onetime items, as I mentioned, in the quarter, but generally given the momentum that have the best leading indicator is the sales production in the first quarter on the enterprise side. I think in general, all the t
componenttext: No, it's not a macro issue. We had some onetime items, as I mentioned, in the quarter, but generally given the momentum that have the best leading indicator is the sales production in the first quarter on the enterprise side. I think in general, all the things we said about EMEA's revenue outlook still holds as for the overall revenue outlook we provided last year, and then Jeff has a few other comments.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Simon, we've talked before about the 4 core markets in EMEA, the U.K., Germany, France and Benelux and our strategy to expand in each of those markets. We've talked about the team that we've brought in and the team that we've been putting together to
componenttext: Yes, Simon, we've talked before about the 4 core markets in EMEA, the U.K., Germany, France and Benelux and our strategy to expand in each of those markets. We've talked about the team that we've brought in and the team that we've been putting together to grow there. But we've really been investing kind of in 4 key areas, which is Metro fiber, continuing to build out to our customers in EMEA, build better Metro access to reach those customers, expanding our product portfolio. We've launched DDoS in EMEA. We have an excellent Ethernet footprint. We have 100 gig wave platform. We've talked about our Voice Complete launch that we're underway with and our security gateways that we've launched in the region. And we're also a spending a lot of time and energy on market awareness and demand generation and then the expansion of the sales channel. So I've talked about some of the people that we've hired in the past, but we've also been now hiring down a layer below that. So in the U.K., we've hired Mike Kennedy, who's a long-term Level 3 employee, but to focus on we driving those investments in EMEA and driving our sales performance and in particular our enterprise sales performance. Bart [ph] in Benelux, another long-term Level 3 employee, but now focused on making sure we're making the right investments in Benelux and driving the growth. In France and Germany, we've hired new people from outside Terry [ph] in France and Ralph Strausburger [ph] in Germany. So we think we're continuing to augment the team. We're very excited about it. We're glad about the momentum that Sunit talked about on the sales and in particular enterprise sales. So we think we're doing the right things and think that team's doing well.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Feldman with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And definitely welcome back to Jeff. Jeff, while you're out, Sunit did a great job with the cost structure. I was hoping we can get a little bit of color on some of the key things you were able to do there. Is it all recurring in the run rate at this poin
componenttext: And definitely welcome back to Jeff. Jeff, while you're out, Sunit did a great job with the cost structure. I was hoping we can get a little bit of color on some of the key things you were able to do there. Is it all recurring in the run rate at this point? Or is there anything that could cause cost to creep higher as we move through the balance of the year?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would say the 3 categories of cost is network expense or Network Access costs. There's -- within the SG&A side, there's headcount-related expense and nonheadcount-related expense. Within the headcount-related expense, we generally expect to grow that
componenttext: So I would say the 3 categories of cost is network expense or Network Access costs. There's -- within the SG&A side, there's headcount-related expense and nonheadcount-related expense. Within the headcount-related expense, we generally expect to grow that expense a little because as I say, we are adding to our sales organization. We'll be adding to our service delivery, service organizations a little whatever support we need to increase the revenue momentum. We are investing more for network expansion. So we might need the people there. On the nonheadcount side, I think we will continue to hold those expenses down pretty tight, maybe even achieve further reductions. And within the Network Access costs, in general, we're looking to make investments to drive more off-net circuit costs on-net but, at the same time, we will have a revenue growth, which will drive the network expense up. So I think that the key is looking at the margins, which should expand a little bit over the course of the year.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions if I may. First on the guidance raise to EBITDA, just curious why we have seen a similar raise to free cash flow on the lower end, particularly with you reducing your interest expense guidance. And then my second question. Curious if you sti
componenttext: Two questions if I may. First on the guidance raise to EBITDA, just curious why we have seen a similar raise to free cash flow on the lower end, particularly with you reducing your interest expense guidance. And then my second question. Curious if you still see enough sizable M&A opportunities that are out there? Or do you think that a buyback is becoming incrementally more likely when we take into consideration your target leverage and where we think you'll be likely exiting the year?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the first question, yes. I mean, you're right between the EBITDA raise, the midpoint raise of that was about $13 million, the interest expense, cash interest expense savings was about $10 million. We didn't really change the cash flow guidance.
componenttext: Yes. So on the first question, yes. I mean, you're right between the EBITDA raise, the midpoint raise of that was about $13 million, the interest expense, cash interest expense savings was about $10 million. We didn't really change the cash flow guidance. So all in all together, that's a $23 million increase on the cash side. I think we'll look at that over the remainder of the year but, at the same time, we also think it's important to have the flexibility to invest in capital expenditures if we see opportunities there for new contract wins or further expansions. So we'll look and see how the year progresses and come back and comment on that.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Colby, with the second question and this is -- you heard this answer before, but we firmly believe that putting excess cash to work is accretive to stockholder value, and our priorities are investing in the business for organic growth and disciplined
componenttext: And Colby, with the second question and this is -- you heard this answer before, but we firmly believe that putting excess cash to work is accretive to stockholder value, and our priorities are investing in the business for organic growth and disciplined M&A. We have a long-term strategy that we want to continue to execute on and believe the best use of our cash is to do that. However, absent those opportunities, returning cash to stockholders makes perfect sense to us. So we will continue to look at that with the bias toward investing our money and growing the business.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Jeff, any color on when we could expect some type of decision as it relates to that process? I mean, as I'm sure you can appreciate, you are getting towards that lower end. Are the range likely by the end of this year, maybe early 2017? Is that likely the period when you would have to make that decision? Or could we see something as it relates to buyback program being instituted perhaps a little bit earlier?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I'm hesitant to give firm time lines on any of this stuff, but I will tell you that it's a serious consideration for us as a company, and our Board of Directors is focused on this issue as well. So again, our primary goal is to find opportunities
componenttext: Yes, and I'm hesitant to give firm time lines on any of this stuff, but I will tell you that it's a serious consideration for us as a company, and our Board of Directors is focused on this issue as well. So again, our primary goal is to find opportunities to invest in our growth. If we can't find that, then the board will sit down and say, "Okay, what should we be doing with our cash." And I apologize for being hesitant to give specific time lines, but we'll look at it over the coming months with the board.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Del Deo with MoffettNathanson LLC.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It looks like there are going to be some changes in special access market or I guess, services, in large part, because of your efforts. And I realized it's hard to have any firm opinions because we don't know what the final rules are. But if they're imple
componenttext: It looks like there are going to be some changes in special access market or I guess, services, in large part, because of your efforts. And I realized it's hard to have any firm opinions because we don't know what the final rules are. But if they're implemented at something approximating the outline that's been laid out by Chairman, can you at least help us dimension what you think? Or how material you might think the impact might be?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So your comments are exactly right, Nick. First of all, it's hard to comment without really knowing the rules. The vote's supposed to be today, maybe taking place right now as we speak. So we'll know more in the coming days as the rules actually come
componenttext: Yes. So your comments are exactly right, Nick. First of all, it's hard to comment without really knowing the rules. The vote's supposed to be today, maybe taking place right now as we speak. So we'll know more in the coming days as the rules actually come out, but we strongly support a competitive marketplace and believe the elimination of the demand lockup agreements will create a more competitive industry and fuel investment and innovation and opportunity for Level 3. We think it's good for our customers. We think it's good for our company. We think it's good for the U.S. economy. So while we'll wait and see what the vote actually turns out to be, what the orders turn out to be, we think that Chairman Wheeler's proposal that we've heard about are all very positive steps for us, and we appreciate the fact that the SEC is looking at these important issues.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then maybe I can ask one more then. The last quarter or 2 there's been a real surge in at least investor interest in small cells. Can you give us some thoughts on the topic and whether or not you think it's going to material source of revenue fo
componenttext: Okay, and then maybe I can ask one more then. The last quarter or 2 there's been a real surge in at least investor interest in small cells. Can you give us some thoughts on the topic and whether or not you think it's going to material source of revenue for you guys?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think yes, we're just at the front edges of seeing that from our wireless customers, and I think compared to the -- compare and contrast to the tower opportunity, which started off as really low bandwidth and kind of took a while before it the aver
componenttext: Yes. I think yes, we're just at the front edges of seeing that from our wireless customers, and I think compared to the -- compare and contrast to the tower opportunity, which started off as really low bandwidth and kind of took a while before it the average demand went up by a fair bit. The small cell opportunities in highly population dense areas, highly urban areas network goes through some of those areas. So on the increment, I think it could create opportunities for us to take advantage of that and increase or expand our network in some of these geographies. But I think we're still at the early stages, and in our situation, we'd had to look at the return opportunities we have to like buildings on that, but it's early. It's still a little early to evaluate, but we do think it's an opportunity because we think small cells, the average demand that companies will look for will be higher right up the gate compared to what happened in the tower situation.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Goldman with Jefferies.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome back, Jeff. Glad to have you. I guess, 2 questions. One just want to return to the cost side and the EBITDA performance for the quarter. I realize you're not going to give us synergy numbers going forward, but I'm just trying to get a sense for I
componenttext: Welcome back, Jeff. Glad to have you. I guess, 2 questions. One just want to return to the cost side and the EBITDA performance for the quarter. I realize you're not going to give us synergy numbers going forward, but I'm just trying to get a sense for I think as we exited last year, the network expense synergies were sort of trailing behind where expectations had been. So wondering if part of what we saw in the EBITDA side of the equation this quarter was driven by maybe an acceleration in those synergies as opposed to just other cost-cutting activity. And then secondly, just North America enterprise, if you look at the supplementals, it looks like 2.2% constant currencies sequential growth, a good number out of the gate. I think 1Q is historically is a slower quarter, and then we usually see it ramp throughout the year. Sunit, you mentioned bookings were strong and expectations going forward there. So just wondering how we should think about North America enterprise and the ability to continue to grow in above 2% sequential growth rate there.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So I'll take the second part first and come to the expenses. So with respect to North America again as Jeff outlined in his remarks, our goal out there is to grow 8% year-over-year. And so I think back to the sequential performance, the sequent
componenttext: All right. So I'll take the second part first and come to the expenses. So with respect to North America again as Jeff outlined in his remarks, our goal out there is to grow 8% year-over-year. And so I think back to the sequential performance, the sequential performance is lumpy in any given quarter there, onetime items and various other things involved. So 2% would mean anywhere from 1.5% to 2.5% or 1.5% [indiscernible] to 2.49%. So I think it's tough to really take anything from 1 quarter, but generally, I mean, our goal is to -- if we can achieve approximately 2%, which is 2 plus or minus 0.5 because it is lumpy when you look at sequential, then we should see the year-over-year growth trend improve, and that's really our goal on that front. As far as the cost flows, I think when you look at either the year-over-year or sequential changes on the cost side, certainly on the network expense side, we have been reducing what are called the fixed part of Network Access cost from optimization. So we did manage to do that sequentially in the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter. So that helped. Similarly, we had further optimization on circuit costs. So we did see the benefit on Network Access costs. So they went down from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. So we are seeing that benefit and also we achieved some reductions on the nonheadcount side of the house. I think both those things is what helped drive the cost out.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Phil Cusick with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Phil Cusick with JPMorgan.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Eric for Phil. Jeff, it's good to have you back. So the colocation data center services, transport fiber all declined in the quarter both sequentially and year-over-year. Can you give us some color on what's driving the decline in each one of thos
componenttext: This is Eric for Phil. Jeff, it's good to have you back. So the colocation data center services, transport fiber all declined in the quarter both sequentially and year-over-year. Can you give us some color on what's driving the decline in each one of those segments?

I think the transport services had more to do with a couple of things. One, the year-over-year comparison. Remember last year we had and there's some professional service and other fees in there, we had some onetime items for Starbucks and the Fed, our federal business it's what's impacting the [indiscernible] comparisons so those should generally improve over the course of the year.

componenttext: Yes, on colocation data -- I mean, I think well no, that's -- the second part of the question I think you asked was on the transport side, and that's what I was answering with respect to Starbucks and Fed. Colocation was what I answered first, which is the businesses sort of been flattish, but I think that with some of the investments we've been making especially in LatAm and some of our strategy work on our cloud connectivity platforms, we should start seeing a little better performance over the next year.

componenttext: Got it, and if I could one more, you talked about CDN growth of 4% in the quarter. And if I recall correctly, that's about roughly 2% of your CNS revenues. With Google moving into the CDN space, what kind of impact are you seeing or anticipating?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, at this point, we're not seeing as much of an impact. I think the bigger impact is if you look at the remarks from Akamai and others has more to do with some of the larger guys doing more self-service. This is a large market. We think our st
componenttext: Well, I mean, at this point, we're not seeing as much of an impact. I think the bigger impact is if you look at the remarks from Akamai and others has more to do with some of the larger guys doing more self-service. This is a large market. We think our strategy is executing well for us. So we continue to think that we should be able to play well in this market, and we focus a lot also on the media side, the media vertical, and that's also doing well, of course. So we don't -- I mean, we haven't seen any current impact. Obviously, over time, it could impact us, but it's still too early.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Christopher on for John. First of all, welcome back, Jeff. Revisiting the M&A question, can you remind us of what your criteria are as you evaluate M&A opportunities? And would you say that you're, in general, hesitant to take on a declining reven
componenttext: This is Christopher on for John. First of all, welcome back, Jeff. Revisiting the M&A question, can you remind us of what your criteria are as you evaluate M&A opportunities? And would you say that you're, in general, hesitant to take on a declining revenue business, and I think you've mentioned previously you're sub scale in EMEA. So with this region be the primary focus at this point?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the criteria our businesses we think create value for our shareholders. So we have actually been pretty aggressive about taking on declining businesses in the past. If you think about WilTel, we acquired WilTel at the time where its largest custom
componenttext: Yes. So the criteria our businesses we think create value for our shareholders. So we have actually been pretty aggressive about taking on declining businesses in the past. If you think about WilTel, we acquired WilTel at the time where its largest customer was SBC. SBC had just acquired AT&T and was migrating traffic, and so we've actually been pretty successful at buying some aspects of declining businesses, taking the strength of the growing businesses and offsetting the weaknesses from the declining business. So I wouldn't say that that's our preferred, but it's also not something that scares us away. We look at companies for a variety of different reasons: capabilities that we don't have, products and services that we don't have. If you look at our relatively small security acquisition of Black Lotus, it's because they had capabilities that we were wanting to put in our product road map. We thought that it was the best way to get them into the product road map is just to acquire the capabilities and deploy them over our entire footprint, and so we'll keep looking at those things. We look for synergies. We look for customers. We look for network capabilities. Those are all the different types of parameters that go into making those decisions.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I would say if you look at what we've done in the past, we like to continue to expand our network footprint. So a lot of facilities-based acquisitions and some enterprise customers and also from a financial perspective, things that are accretive
componenttext: Yes, and I would say if you look at what we've done in the past, we like to continue to expand our network footprint. So a lot of facilities-based acquisitions and some enterprise customers and also from a financial perspective, things that are accretive to free cash flow per share after a short integration period. So that's the financial criteria.

componenttext: First of all, we don't ever comment on particular opportunities, but you're exactly right. We do think there are opportunities in EMEA, and we think there are opportunities in Latin America, and so we're very active and engaged. We believe it's our entire job to make sure we're out on every opportunity that's out there and that we're looking at all the different areas of opportunities. We have a great business in Latin America. We have an excellent team. We have great customers, and we want to continue to augment that as we can. The same is true in EMEA, and I don't know if you want to add anything to that.

And then secondly, just on the North American wholesale side. With -- I think you're looking for your prior aspirations of modest improvement year-over-year in 2016. With the business down I think about 90 basis points in the first quarter, do you still same outlook for the year? Or are you revisiting that outlook?

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think on the outlook, we have the same outlook for the year. And as we indicated, forward-looking indicators look good whether sales bookings. And then on the noncash comp, as I said, some of it was -- is underestimation. One was a retirement el
componenttext: Yes. So I think on the outlook, we have the same outlook for the year. And as we indicated, forward-looking indicators look good whether sales bookings. And then on the noncash comp, as I said, some of it was -- is underestimation. One was a retirement eligible, and the second thing, to your point, was on performance-based stock grants, which are driven by growth objectives. So it was underestimation there. Those are really the 2 key reasons. We are generally pretty good about estimating this, and I have to say that we underestimated, but I think the new guidance that we have should incorporate everything.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that was our last question. So I'd like to close the call with a few thoughts. First of all, I'm happy to be back. I feel very fortunate to be part of a great company and a great team of employees. So I'm happy to be here. Also our focus on profitab
componenttext: Well, that was our last question. So I'd like to close the call with a few thoughts. First of all, I'm happy to be back. I feel very fortunate to be part of a great company and a great team of employees. So I'm happy to be here. Also our focus on profitable growth was evident in our first quarter results as we expanded margins and generated strong free cash flow. With the transformation the hybrid networking underway and enterprise communications, we are focused on meeting the needs of our customers. We do it with innovative and differentiated products, delivering better top line growth as market continues to move toward the core capabilities that Level 3 offers. We believe that our vision of one, one set of products, one network, one set of systems and one team is key to providing a superior customer experience and accelerating growth. And our guiding principle for several years, increasing our free cash flow per share, continues to be fundamental to our business model. Thank you for joining today's call and for your continued support of Level 3. Operator, that concludes the call.

headline: Level 3 Communications, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
